SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, an old inhabited area, home to 6 pueblos, and a vital habitat for migratory birds. The area provides water to many in New Mexico and should be maintained to protect endangered species, the river flow, and be more accessible to the public. The Corps of Engineers should prioritize environmental restoration and reestablish hydrologic connections where possible. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, providing water to many in New Mexico. It is home to 6 pueblos, a vital habitat for migratory birds, and should be maintained to protect endangered species and the river flow. The Corps of Engineers should prioritize environmental restoration and reestablish hydrologic connections for healthy vegetation growth. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Critical restoration project: Project under this Act producing immediate ecosystem benefits.
Middle Rio Grande: Portion of Rio Grande in New Mexico.
Secretary: Secretary of the Army.

SEC. 3. MIDDLE RIO GRANDE RESTORATION. The Secretary will conduct critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting projects based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing studies and plans. Local participation from public and private entities active in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed is required. Cost-sharing agreements must be established before project implementation. Before carrying out critical restoration projects, the Secretary must enter into cost-sharing agreements with non-Federal interests. These agreements require non-Federal interests to pay 25% of total project costs, provide necessary land and resources, cover operation and maintenance costs, and hold the United States harmless from any claims. The non-Federal interests must pay for any recreational features exceeding 30% of the total project cost in critical restoration projects. They will receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if the work they perform is deemed integral to the project by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
